text.p: Union Carbide Corp said it will add a 40 million pound-per-year diethylenetriamine (DETA) production unit to its ethyleneamines operations at Taft, La.
Carbide said the plans are "in response to strong worldwide demand."

The company said the new unit will be fully integrated with the Taft plant's existing ethyleneamines facility and its new ethanolamines plant, currently under construction. Start-up is planned for late 1999, bringing the company's total ethyleneamines capacity to 270 million pounds per year.

"The new facility will employ Union Carbide's proprietary, ethylene oxide-based technology, which produces DETA with few co-products," said Gordon D. Mounts, vice president and general manager -- Industrial Performance Chemicals.

DETA is used in the manufacture of wet-strength paper resins, chelating agents, polyamides, epoxy curing agents, corrosion inhibitors and many other industrial products. Worldwide demand for DETA is expected to outpace global economic growth for the next several years, Carbide said.
